Extreme Close-Up.prompt: focus exclusively on eyes or mouth, clinical proximity, high-detail textures, zero environment visibility

Face Portrait.prompt: tight framing from top of head to chin, emphasis on facial expression and skin texture, blurred background

Bust Shot.prompt: framing from head to mid-chest, standard portrait crop, stable shoulders, professional headshot aesthetic

Waist-Up (Medium Shot): framing from head to waist, capturing hand gestures and torso, balanced character-environment interaction
Knee-Up (Medium Long): cinematic framing from head to just below knees, showing clothing style and stance, classic storytelling crop
Full Body Shot: head-to-toe framing, clear view of feet and ground contact, emphasizing posture and full attire

Wide Full Body.prompt: character is small in the frame, significant environment visibility on all sides, 35mm wide-angle aesthetic

Micro-Texture.prompt: extreme 1:1 macro focus on surface material, visible fibers and pores, hyper-realistic tactile detail, shallow depth of field

Circuitry & Tech Close-up: microscopic view of electronic traces and solder points, metallic reflections, technical industrial aesthetic, macro-lens precision
Organic Cellular Pattern: abstract macro of natural growth patterns, leaf veins or skin cell structures, soft organic lighting, microscopic biological focus
Crystal & Mineral Lattice: sharp macro focus on crystalline facets, internal light refractions, geometric mineral structures, hyper-detailed geological aesthetic
Fabric Weave Detail: extreme close-up on textile interlacing, visible thread count and fuzz, soft shadow depth between fibers, macro-fashion focus
Liquid Droplet Dynamics: macro shot of water tension and droplets, distorted refractions through liquid, high-speed shutter aesthetic, crystalline clarity

Iris & Pupil Geometry.prompt: microscopic focus on the human eye, intricate stromal patterns, wet surface gloss, hyper-detailed eyelashes, medical-grade macro

Extreme Telephoto Compression: 200mm+ lens effect, flattened spatial layers, background elements appearing massive and close to the subject, narrow field of view
Wide-Angle Spatial Expansion: 14mm rectilinear lens, exaggerated distance between foreground and background, deep environmental immersion, peripheral stretching
Fisheye Barrel Distortion: 180-degree spherical field of view, extreme curved horizon, warped peripheral geometry, ultra-wide immersive bubble effect
Tilt-Shift (Miniature Effect): selective focus blur on top and bottom of frame, simulating a toy-like miniature scale, artificial depth-of-field manipulation
Anamorphic Squeeze: 2.39:1 cinematic ratio, subtle horizontal lens flares, oval-shaped bokeh, wide lateral field of view with professional film optics
Soft-Focus Glow: intentional spherical aberration, glowing highlights, dreamlike ethereal atmosphere, vintage romantic lens aesthetic
Deep Focus (Infinite Depth): high f-stop aesthetic, maximum clarity from immediate foreground to distant horizon, sharp architectural and landscape layers
Environmental Portrait: subject occupies 30% of the frame, balanced interaction with surroundings, wide-prime lens, storytelling through context and background detail
Tiny Subject (Ant-Scale): extreme wide vista, subject as a microscopic focal point in a massive environment, emphasizing isolation and vastness, hyper-scale landscape
Centered Dominance: subject placed dead-center, zero-offset composition, high visual weight, commanding presence within a balanced symmetrical frame
Leading Negative Space: subject positioned on one edge looking into vast empty space, emphasizing direction, anticipation, and minimalist composition
Head-to-Toe Precision: full-body framing with equal clearance above head and below feet, 35mm lens, natural anatomical proportions, stable ground-plane visibility
Object-Centric Product Frame: hero-shot positioning for inanimate objects, 45-degree downward angle, soft studio lighting, focus on form and silhouette over environment
Crowd Integration: subject partially obscured or blended into a dense group, shallow depth of field to isolate one face among many, chaotic but focused framing
One-Point Perspective: perfectly centered vanishing point, symmetrical lines receding toward the middle, architectural hallway or street alignment, Kubrick-style precision
Diagonal Leading Lines: dynamic composition using structural edges to lead the eye from corners toward the subject, high-energy geometric arrangement
Corner-to-Corner Depth: camera placed in a high or low corner to maximize spatial volume, 14mm rectilinear wide-angle, emphasizing three-dimensional room geometry
Low-Angle Pillar Shot: camera at floor level looking up at vertical structures, exaggerated height, converging vertical lines, sense of awe and massive scale
Orthographic Top-Down: perfect 90-degree overhead view of architectural floor plans or furniture, zero perspective distortion, flat geometric mapping aesthetic
Symmetrical Portal Framing: using arches, doorways, or windows as a secondary frame, centered alignment, depth-within-depth composition
Cantilever Perspective: framing from a protruding edge or balcony, looking out over a drop, emphasizing structural overhang and vertical void
Through-the-Glass (Refracted): shooting through textured, frosted, or wet glass, light distortions and soft bokeh artifacts, layered transparent depth, intimate observation
Framed by Architecture: using a physical structure like an archway, window, or pillars to border the main subject, creating a formal frame-within-a-frame effect
Obscured View (Foliage): camera positioned behind plants or branches, out-of-focus natural elements in the extreme foreground, peek-a-boo depth and organic borders
Venetian Blind Shadow-Frame: subject framed by rhythmic horizontal light and shadow patterns, high-contrast film noir aesthetic, graphic atmospheric layering
Reflection-Primary Framing: subject seen primarily through a puddle, mirror, or polished surface, inverted composition, double-image depth and artistic symmetry
Silhouetted Foreground Frame: using dark, underexposed shapes in the foreground (like a doorway or cave mouth) to frame a brightly lit subject in the distance
Bokeh-Wash Framing: extreme out-of-focus foreground elements (like city lights or flowers) taking up 40% of the frame, creating a soft, colorful atmospheric border
Slot-View (Gap Reveal): framing through a narrow horizontal or vertical gap, restricting the view to a specific slice of the scene, high-tension voyeuristic feel
Anamorphic 2.39:1 Scope: extreme cinematic widescreen, oval bokeh, horizontal blue lens flares, professional movie-still framing with massive lateral space
Academy 4:3 Vintage: boxy classical framing, centered subject focus, emphasizing height and vertical composition, 1940s-1950s film aesthetic
IMAX 1.43:1 Vertical Scale: massive vertical and horizontal field of view, expansive environmental detail, immersive high-resolution framing for grand scale
Letterboxed Vista: widescreen aspect ratio with permanent black cinematic bars (top/bottom), wide-angle lens, high-end post-production aesthetic
Golden Spiral Composition: fibonacci sequence-based framing, subject placed at the focal point of a natural curve, organic visual flow and mathematical balance
Centered Symmetry (Wes Anderson Style): perfectly balanced left-and-right elements, dead-center subject, flat perspective, meticulous and quirky architectural framing
Extreme Vignette / Pinhole: heavy dark circular borders, focused central clarity, primitive camera aesthetic, high psychological focal intensity
Canted Wide-Frame: 15-degree Dutch angle combined with 2.39:1 widescreen, high-tension cinematic action framing, diagonal horizon energy

Orthographic Map View.prompt: perfect 90-degree downward perspective, flattened topographical aesthetic, zero perspective distortion, world-map or blueprint feel

Nadir Point Perspective: straight down-view from extreme height, focusing on the intersection of ground planes and textures, geometric urban grid layout

Satellite Survey Frame.prompt: extreme high-altitude, atmospheric haze on edges, narrow field of view to simulate orbital sensor, high-tech surveillance aesthetic

Tilt-Shift Urban Miniature: high-angle drone framing with artificial shallow depth of field, making cityscapes or crowds look like tiny toy models
Top-Down Oblique: high-altitude 45-degree angle, showing both the top surfaces and side elevations of structures, technical architectural survey
Horizon-to-Horizon Panoramic: ultra-wide horizontal sweep, capturing the curve of the earth or the full expanse of a landscape, 32:9 extreme cinematic ratio
Cloud-Level Glide: framing from within or just above a cloud layer, subject partially obscured by mist, ethereal and expansive scale
Minimalist Negative Space: subject pushed to the extreme corner of the frame, 90% empty background, focusing on color fields and atmospheric weight
Macro-Abstract Geometry: extreme close-up on an object where its function is lost, focusing only on lines, shadows, and textures to create a new shape
Double Exposure Framing: two distinct frames overlaid, subject silhouette containing a secondary environment, surreal dream-logic composition
Fragmented Mirror Mosaic: subject reflected in multiple broken glass shards, repeating and distorted facial or body elements, chaotic artistic depth
Light-Leaked Border: intentional optical flaw framing, soft orange or red light flares bleeding from the edges, vintage analog film-burn aesthetic
Motion-Blur Framing: subject is sharp while the entire frame edges are streaked with long-exposure motion blur, sense of warping through space
Shadow-Play Silhouette: framing the subject entirely through their shadow cast on a textured wall, no direct view of the subject, conceptual and mysterious
Prism Distortion: rainbow-edged light refractions, multiple ghost images of the subject created by glass prism interference, psychedelic optical stunts
